description: From Middle English urbanitie, from Middle French urbanité, from Latin urbānitās, from urbānus (“belonging to a city”), with a sense of "having the manners of townspeople" in Classical Latin, from urbs (“city”); equivalent to urban +‎ -ity.

entries.meaning: Behaviour that is polished, refined, courteous.
examples: The vaunted courtesy of the old school, the smooth urbanity that prevailed in former days [...]
[...], the majority of cases will differ as to "urbanity", as most of the evacuees were rural.
